statistical area, based on the 2000 Census.]]



The 'BaltimoreâWashington metropolitan area' is a combined statistical area
consisting of the overlapping labor market region of the cities of Baltimore,
Maryland and Washington, District of Columbia. The region includes Central
Maryland, Northern Virginia, two counties in the Eastern Panhandle of West
Virginia, and one county in South Central Pennsylvania. It is the most educated,
highest-income, and fourth largest combined statistical area in the United
States. [http://www.greaterbaltimore.org/tabid/534/Default.aspx CSA Median
household income] [http://triangle.bizjournals.com/triangle/stories/2-
009/09/21/daily23.html?ana=tt3245 RaleighâDurham area ranks third in U.S. for
college degrees]

Officially, the area is designated by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB)
as the 'Washington-Baltimore-Arlington, DC-MD-VA-WV-PA Combined Statistical
Area'. It is composed primarily of two major metropolitan statistical areas, the
[[Baltimore-Towson Metropolitan Statistical Area|Baltimore-Columbia-Towson, MD]]
[[Metropolitan Statistical Area|MSA]] and the [[Washington Metropolitan
Area|WashingtonâArlingtonâAlexandria, DCâVAâMDâWV]] MSA. In addition, six other
smaller urban areas not contiguous to the main urban area but having strong
commuting ties with the main area are also included in the metropolitan area. http://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/default/files/omb/bulletins/2013/b-
13-01.pdf These are: the [[Hagerstown metropolitan area|Hagerstown-
Martinsburg, MD-WV]] MSA, the [[Franklin County, PA|Chambersburg-Waynesboro,
PA]] MSA, the [[Winchester, VAâWV MSA|Winchester, VAâWV]] MSA, the [[Lexington
Park|California-Lexington Park, MD]] MSA, the [[Talbot County, MD|Easton, MD]]
[[micropolitan statistical area]] (ÂµSA), and the [[Dorchester County,
MD|Cambridge, MD]] ÂµSA.

Some counties and cities are not officially designated by the OMB as members of
this metropolitan area, but still consider themselves members anyway. This is
mostly due to their proximity to the area, the size of their commuter
population, and by the influence of local broadcasting stations. The population
of the entire BaltimoreâWashington Metroplex as of the Census Bureau's 2012
Population Estimates is 9,331,587. http://www.census.gov/popest/data/metro/totals/2012/tables/CBSA-

eneral/List6.txt List6.txt] The most populous city is Washington, DC, with
a population of 632,323. The most populous county is Fairfax County,
Virginia, with a population exceeding 1 million.
